title: Justice Department to Allow Body Cameras in Joint Task Forces
text:
CHICAGO—The Justice Department for the first time will let police officers wear body cameras during some joint operations with federal agents, lifting a ban that had long frustrated local agencies, department officials said.

Federal law enforcement officers will still be banned from using the devices while hunting fugitives or searching buildings, the officials said, a contradiction that highlights the challenges of developing more formal guidelines governing their use.

While a growing number of police departments across the U.S. require body cameras for public accountability, the federal government maintains that recording federal agents’ work would jeopardize sensitive investigations, a policy that has also applied to local police who work on joint task forces.

A pilot program in at least six cities aims to strike a balance by allowing officers to wear the cameras only during some arrests and while executing search warrants, senior Justice Department officials said. But they would leave the cameras behind during missions involving confidential informants, classified information and national-security concerns. For example, the Federal Bureau of Investigation’s Joint Terrorism Task Force, which investigates potential terrorist attacks, would be prohibited from ever using the cameras.

Department officials said they hope a trial period of 90 days or longer will help answer major outstanding questions, including how footage should be stored and used in court cases; when cameras should be turned on or off; and how they should be used around undercover agents who require anonymity for sensitive cases.

The test run, which comes after months of deliberations with officials from the FBI, the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, the U.S. Marshals and the Drug Enforcement Administration, will take place in about six midsize cities, the officials said.

The body camera shift is being announced at a national gathering of local and federal law-enforcement officials in Chicago.

Hundreds of officers across the country participate in such joint missions, and both federal and local authorities have said they find the cooperation a valuable way to share information as they investigate everything from drug trafficking to gang crime and bank robberies. But tension over the dueling body camera policies has been brewing for months, The Wall Street Journal reported.

Justice Department officials acknowledged that a policy change is a massive undertaking, driven by years of concerns from local police departments about the ban. The issue came to a head in May after Atlanta Police Chief Erika Shields withdrew from federal task forces citing the ban, which clashed with a local policy requiring the devices. Other police departments had also been considering removing their officers from federal task forces.

Yet federal law enforcement groups expressed concern that recording their work would have a chilling effect on confidential informants.

Houston Police Chief Art Acevedo said he was pleased that the department acted quickly to address concerns shared by many departments. He leads the Major Cities Chiefs Association, which pushed for changes and helped draft the test run.

“It is a recognition on their part of the importance to our membership and the communities we serve…and of the value that we bring to those task forces,” he said.

Mr. Acevedo acknowledged officials are still sorting out the details but said he hopes the trial run will lead to a permanent, nationwide policy.
